handNote.p: Ker's scribe '(4)' of 'seven or eight'. Ker describes this script as a 'set hand like that used at Exeter about the time of the Conquest', one used by both this scribe and another scribe, Ker's scribe '(8)'. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule. Round, unroofed a; a mixture of descending insular long s and tall s; round d with short ascender; ash is of oe-form. Ascenders are forked. e is horned, with a short tongue. Thorn tends to have a somewhat short descender. Though the scribe draws a round, unroofed a-form, he frequently inexactly connects the belly stroke and minim stroke at the top such that a frequently has a hint of an accidental roof. This scribe is also responsible for a number of small c-shaped accents that indicate short vowel quality, particularly for disambiguating between god/'God' and gōd/'good'. See further Ker's Catalogue on the script's relationship to several MSS of Exeter. There appears no overt evidence of emending or correcting hands. Many very subtly executed self-corrections of i to dotted y, suggesting an exemplar with i-spellings. A similar i/dotted y tendency is apparent in 144.04, though the corrections are much more obvious there.
